awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Disposable All-Graphene Microfluidic Biosensor System for Real-Time Foodborne Pathogen Detection in Food Processing Facilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Disease-causing bacteria found in food causes 48 million illnesses and $15.6 billion in health-related costs annually in the U.S. alone. This project will create bacteria testing technology (i.e., sensors) that are cost-effective, rapid, and easy-to-use to ensure wide use in food processing facilities. The sensors will work and look much like a home blood sugar test device that will permit users to test for pathogens from swab samples taken from virtually any surface including equipment and floor drains.  Multiple sensors will be developed and connected to the internet so that measurements can be collected and analyzed simultaneously at a central location. Contamination breakouts will therefore be quickly identified and pinpointed so that appropriate  corrective measures can be taken  prior to the contaminated food reaches the market.  Outreach activities will include hands-on exhibit on sensors and mentoring students in Women Explore Engineering Summer Camp.


Foodborne pathogen detection in processing facilities is infrequently performed because of the cost ($8-10 per test), time (24-48 h for results), and low sensitivity (~100 CFU/mL detection limits that usually require sample pre-enrichment) associated with current laboratory test techniques. Thus, the sources of pathogen contamination are not determined in a timely fashion prior to the contaminated food reaching the consumer. Field deployable foodborne pathogen biosensors that are low-cost, rapid (a few minutes), and highly sensitive (< 5 CFU/mL detection limits) are highly desirable, but currently do not exist. The objective of the proposed work is to develop effective field deployable biosensors for Salmonella in food processing facility that pose high risk for food contamination (e.g., equipment, work surfaces). Multiple biosensors will be created and used within a food processing facility, while the measured data will be streamed to a central location via the internet. Through the Internet of Things (IoT) paradigm the sensor network will enable simultaneous monitoring of pathogens and sanitation efficacy so that appropriate action can be implemented. The proposed biosensor is expected to exhibit a sensitivity comparable to, if not better than, current laboratory-based Salmonella detection methods.  The project specific aims are: Aim 1: Develop a graphene-based microfluidic biosensor system; Aim 2: Biofunctionalize and evaluate the biosensor system for foodborne pathogen detection; Aim 3: Evaluate data from multiple biosensors within a food processing facility via an IoT paradigm. The graphene-based biosensor and corresponding microfluidics system uses inkjet printing and rapid laser-pulse annealing to create graphene surfaces with high electrical conductivity, tunable hydrophobicity, and nanostructured morphologies that can operate synergistically to detect Salmonella with a high sensitivity and without the need for pre-enrichment techniques. The graphene electrodes will be biofunctionalized with aptamers that have binding affinities similar to monoclonal antibodies. The aptamers selectivity to the targeted Salmonella strains will be evaluated within the presence of other potential interferents (e.g., other gram-negative bacteria) in buffer, chicken broth, carcass rinsate, and swab samples. The biosensor will be optimized to negate false positives and false negatives. If the aptamers are not sufficiently sensitive or selective than monoclonal antibodies (e.g. Anti-Salmonella) will be used instead. Small-scale food processing facilities at TAMU, ISU, and AES Controls (industry collaborator) will be used to help validate the sensor system in a food processing setting. Also, the Virtual Reality Applications Center at ISU (Co-PI is the co-director) will directly work in developing this ad-hoc network. Outreach activities the development of an interactive exhibit that displays how nanoscale and microscale patterning induces hydrophobicity,  IoT-based learning modules for underrepresented minority students, hands-on demonstrations on biosensor design and foodborne pathogen detection and mentoring young women in the Women Explore Engineering (WEE) summer camp.

por.por_cntn:
Food contamination in processing facilities can lead to serious public health problems as well as costly recalls of millions of food units. Without advanced detection programs in place, the source of the outbreak is often unknown or difficult to accurately identify. Detection methods that are fast, sensitive, and require little expertise or training are greatly needed for point-of-use settings, particularly for pathogen detection to reduce cost and holding time for food products. The objective of this project was to develop a biosensor system for rapid foodborne pathogen detection (i.e., Salmonella) in food processing facility areas that pose high risk for contamination in food (i.e., food contact and work surfaces, tools, utensil handles, floors, drainage sites, etc.). The biosensors and corresponding sample fluid delivery system (i.e., microfluidic channel) were entirely fabricated of inkjet printed graphene derived from exfoliated flakes of graphite or even coal (i.e., the cheapest material on Earth:  ~ $10-$60 per ton). A laser was used with different power settings in order to make the graphene highly conductive for biosensing or to change the graphene surface to one that attracts water (hydrophilic) to one that repels liquid (hydrophobic) to wick sample fluid to the biosensor. Biomolecules including synthetic DNA-based biomolecules (i.e., aptamers), antibodies, enzymes, and lectins that selectively bind to distinct strains of foodborne pathogens were attached to the biosensor. An electrochemical signal is then generated when foodborne pathogens attach to the biosensor and the signal is monitored with a portable electrical reader in much the same fashion that diabetics monitor their blood glucose levels at home. The research plan was to accomplish the following objectives: Objective 1: Develop a graphene-based microfluidic biosensor system. Objective 2: Biofunctionalize and evaluate the biosensor system for foodborne pathogen detection. Objective 3: Evaluate data from multiple biosensors within a food processing facility via an Internet of Things (IoT) paradigm.

 

During the duration of this project, we worked on developing and improving methods to fabricate graphene-based electrodes that are low-cost, high-yield for electrochemical monitoring of foodborne pathogens. We tested a variety of biorecognition agents for selectivity under the presence of interferents and complex food scenarios. Furthermore, we created simple method to develop open microfluidic platforms by manipulating the surface wettability of spin-coated graphene ink films on flexible polyethylene terephthalate via laser-controlled patterning. Furthermore, multiple microarrays sensors could be easily printed into the hydrophilic microchannel of the proposed biosensor and therefore simultaneous detection of multiple foodborne pathogens could be monitored simultaneously from one swab sample. This project has produced a new understanding of the bio-nano interface in biosensors. This project has produced an optimized method for immobilizing biorecognition agents. It produced a new understanding on engineering graphene-based nanostructures that allows for tuned electrical conductivity and hydrophobicity of low-cost graphene flakes that can be printed in any substrate. Additionally, this produced resulted a new understanding on fabrication of laser induced graphene with tuned hydrophobicity to create open microfluidics and sensing devices amenable to scalable manufacturing using a laser scribing process. This project has assisted in the understanding of sensor efficacy using open-microfluidic and the effect of reduced non-specific adsorption. This study has resulted in a rapid, sensitive tool that has the potential to be integrated in food safety monitoring in food processing facilities.

 

Additionally, this project has trained four graduate students (two female, two Hispanic) and provided research experience to six engineering undergraduate students (two Hispanic, and two female) and two research experience for undergraduate students, all in engineering disciplines. These students were involved in all activities within this report, and in most cases, they were the leaders of the activities. Undergraduate and graduate students had opportunity to present their research achievements at a professional/scientific conference.

 

This project is likely to impact on the commercialization of a rapid, sensitive and portable foodborne pathogen detection tool, which can be integrated into food safety monitoring. Patent applications have been filed and licensing agreements are in place as a result of this project. Moreover, this project is likely to impact on the commercialization of the laser processed graphene and inkjet-printed graphene that is amenable to roll-to-roll manufacturing, which can be used for biosensor’s fabrication. Furthermore, the advantage of this device is that it is able to yield results with a short time frame of minutes, compared to current evaluation time of 8-10 hours to days. This rapid analysis is expected to provide a significant economic advantage over current standard techniques by reducing holding times for laboratory testing and allowing processing plants to optimize intervention strategies. Thus, this project work has a broad positive impact as it has the potential to assist in the development of effective measures for foodborne pathogens control in food processing facilities and consequently improve food safety and ultimately public health.
